trans-unit.source: Azure Search Management REST API Version 2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: Azure Search Management REST API Version 2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: Azure Search Management REST API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: Azure Search Management REST API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: Management API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: Management API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: This document describes the 2014-07-31-Preview version of the Azure Search Management REST API.
trans-unit.target: This document describes the 2014-07-31-Preview version of the Azure Search Management REST API.

trans-unit.source: It has since been replaced by the generally available version, <link><linkText>Azure Search Management REST API 2015-02-28</linkText><title></title></link> on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: It has since been replaced by the generally available version, <link><linkText>Azure Search Management REST API 2015-02-28</linkText><title></title></link> on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Service management operations
trans-unit.target: Service management operations

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search Service Management REST API provides programmatic access to much of the functionality available through the portal, allowing administrators to automate the following operations:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search Service Management REST API provides programmatic access to much of the functionality available through the portal, allowing administrators to automate the following operations:

trans-unit.source: Create or delete an Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: Create or delete an Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: Create, change, or retrieve api-keys to automate regular changes to the administrative keys used for authenticating search data operations.
trans-unit.target: Create, change, or retrieve api-keys to automate regular changes to the administrative keys used for authenticating search data operations.

trans-unit.source: Adjust the scale of an Azure Search service in response to changes in query volume or storage requirements.
trans-unit.target: Adjust the scale of an Azure Search service in response to changes in query volume or storage requirements.

trans-unit.source: To fully administer your service programmatically, you will need two APIs: The Management REST API of Azure Search, plus the common <link><linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To fully administer your service programmatically, you will need two APIs: The Management REST API of Azure Search, plus the common <link><linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Manager API is used for general purpose operations that are not service specific, such as querying subscription data, listing geo-locations, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Manager API is used for general purpose operations that are not service specific, such as querying subscription data, listing geo-locations, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: To create and manage Azure Search services in your subscription, make sure your HTTP request includes the Resource Manager endpoint, subscription ID, provider (in this case, Azure Search), and the Search service-specific operation.
trans-unit.target: To create and manage Azure Search services in your subscription, make sure your HTTP request includes the Resource Manager endpoint, subscription ID, provider (in this case, Azure Search), and the Search service-specific operation.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link> is a walkthrough of sample code that demonstrates application configuration and service management operations.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link> is a walkthrough of sample code that demonstrates application configuration and service management operations.

trans-unit.source: The sample application issues requests to the Azure Resource Manager API as well as the service management API for Azure Search, giving you an idea of how to piece together a cohesive application that draws on both APIs.
trans-unit.target: The sample application issues requests to the Azure Resource Manager API as well as the service management API for Azure Search, giving you an idea of how to piece together a cohesive application that draws on both APIs.

trans-unit.source: Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Endpoint

trans-unit.source: The endpoint for service administration operations is the URL of Azure Resource Manager, https://management.azure.com.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint for service administration operations is the URL of Azure Resource Manager, https://management.azure.com.

trans-unit.source: Note that all management API calls must include the subscription ID and an API version.
trans-unit.target: Note that all management API calls must include the subscription ID and an API version.

trans-unit.source: Versions
trans-unit.target: Versions

trans-unit.source: The current version of the Azure Search Management REST API is api-version=2014-07-31-Preview.
trans-unit.target: The current version of the Azure Search Management REST API is api-version=2014-07-31-Preview.

trans-unit.source: It is the only version of this API.
trans-unit.target: It is the only version of this API.

trans-unit.source: Authentication and Access Control
trans-unit.target: Authentication and Access Control

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search Management REST API is an extension of the Azure Resource Manager and shares its dependencies.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search Management REST API is an extension of the Azure Resource Manager and shares its dependencies.

trans-unit.source: As such, Active Directory is a prerequisite to service administration of Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: As such, Active Directory is a prerequisite to service administration of Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: All administrative requests from client code must be authenticated using Azure Active Directory before the request reaches the resource manager.
trans-unit.target: All administrative requests from client code must be authenticated using Azure Active Directory before the request reaches the resource manager.

trans-unit.source: Note that if your application code handles service management operations as well as data operations on indexes or documents, you'll be using two authentication approaches for each of the Azure Search APIs:
trans-unit.target: Note that if your application code handles service management operations as well as data operations on indexes or documents, you'll be using two authentication approaches for each of the Azure Search APIs:

trans-unit.source: Service and key administration, due to the dependency on Resource Manager, relies on Active Directory for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Service and key administration, due to the dependency on Resource Manager, relies on Active Directory for authentication.

trans-unit.source: Data requests against the Azure Search service endpoint, such as Create Index or Search Documents, use an api-key in the request header.
trans-unit.target: Data requests against the Azure Search service endpoint, such as Create Index or Search Documents, use an api-key in the request header.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Azure Search Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link> for information about authenticating a data request.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Azure Search Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link> for information about authenticating a data request.

trans-unit.source: The sample application documented in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link> demonstrates the authentication techniques for each type of operation.
trans-unit.target: The sample application documented in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link> demonstrates the authentication techniques for each type of operation.

trans-unit.source: Instructions for configuring a client application to use Active Directory are included in the getting started.
trans-unit.target: Instructions for configuring a client application to use Active Directory are included in the getting started.

trans-unit.source: Access control for Azure Resource Manager uses the built-in Owner, Contributor, and Reader roles.
trans-unit.target: Access control for Azure Resource Manager uses the built-in Owner, Contributor, and Reader roles.

trans-unit.source: By default, all service administrators are members of the Owner role.
trans-unit.target: By default, all service administrators are members of the Owner role.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <link><linkText>Role-based access control in Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <link><linkText>Role-based access control in Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Service Operations
trans-unit.target: Service Operations

trans-unit.source: You can provision or deprovision Azure Search services by issuing HTTP requests against your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can provision or deprovision Azure Search services by issuing HTTP requests against your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios enabled through these operations include creating custom administration tools or standing up an end-to-end production or development environment (from service creation, all the way to populating an index).
trans-unit.target: Scenarios enabled through these operations include creating custom administration tools or standing up an end-to-end production or development environment (from service creation, all the way to populating an index).

trans-unit.source: Likewise, solution vendors who design and sell cloud solutions might want an automated, repeatable approach for provisioning services for each new customer.
trans-unit.target: Likewise, solution vendors who design and sell cloud solutions might want an automated, repeatable approach for provisioning services for each new customer.

trans-unit.source: Create Search Service
trans-unit.target: Create Search Service

trans-unit.source: The Create Search Service operation provisions a new Search service with the specified parameters.
trans-unit.target: The Create Search Service operation provisions a new Search service with the specified parameters.

trans-unit.source: This API can also be used to update an existing service definition.
trans-unit.target: This API can also be used to update an existing service definition.

trans-unit.source: Request URI Parameters
trans-unit.target: Request URI Parameters

trans-unit.source: subscriptionId: Required.
trans-unit.target: subscriptionId: Required.

trans-unit.source: The subscriptionID for the Azure user.
trans-unit.target: The subscriptionID for the Azure user.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain this value from the Azure Resource Manager API or the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can obtain this value from the Azure Resource Manager API or the portal.

trans-unit.source: resourceGroupName: Required.
trans-unit.target: resourceGroupName: Required.

trans-unit.source: The name of the resource group within the user’s subscription.
trans-unit.target: The name of the resource group within the user’s subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain this value from the Azure Resource Manager API or the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can obtain this value from the Azure Resource Manager API or the portal.

trans-unit.source: serviceName: Required. The name of the search service within the specified resource group. Service names must only contain lowercase letters, digits or dashes, cannot use dash as the first two or last one characters, cannot contain consecutive dashes, and must be between 2 and 15 characters in length. Since all names end up being .search.windows.net, service names must be globally unique. No two services either within or across subscriptions and resource groups can have the same name. You cannot change the service name after it is created.
trans-unit.target: serviceName: Required. The name of the search service within the specified resource group. Service names must only contain lowercase letters, digits or dashes, cannot use dash as the first two or last one characters, cannot contain consecutive dashes, and must be between 2 and 15 characters in length. Since all names end up being .search.windows.net, service names must be globally unique. No two services either within or across subscriptions and resource groups can have the same name. You cannot change the service name after it is created.

trans-unit.source: api-version: Required.
trans-unit.target: api-version: Required.

trans-unit.source: Specifies the version of the protocol used for this request.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the version of the protocol used for this request.

trans-unit.source: As newer versions become available, you can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors.
trans-unit.target: As newer versions become available, you can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors.

trans-unit.source: Request Headers
trans-unit.target: Request Headers

trans-unit.source: Content-Type: Required.
trans-unit.target: Content-Type: Required.

trans-unit.source: Set this header to application/json.
trans-unit.target: Set this header to application/json.

trans-unit.source: x-ms-client-request-id: Optional.
trans-unit.target: x-ms-client-request-id: Optional.

trans-unit.source: A client-generated GUID value that identifies this request.
trans-unit.target: A client-generated GUID value that identifies this request.

trans-unit.source: If specified, this will be included in response information as a way to map the request.
trans-unit.target: If specified, this will be included in response information as a way to map the request.

trans-unit.target: Request Body

trans-unit.target: "location": "location of search service",

trans-unit.source: "tags": {
trans-unit.target: "tags": {

trans-unit.source: "key": "value",
trans-unit.target: "key": "value",

trans-unit.target: "properties": {

trans-unit.target: "sku": {

trans-unit.target: "name": "free | standard | standard2"

trans-unit.source: "replicaCount": 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6,
trans-unit.target: "replicaCount": 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6,

trans-unit.target: "partitionCount": 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 6 | 12

trans-unit.source: Request Body Parameters
trans-unit.target: Request Body Parameters

trans-unit.source: location: Required.
trans-unit.target: location: Required.

trans-unit.source: One of the supported and registered Azure Geo Regions (for example, West US, East US, Southeast Asia, and so on).
trans-unit.target: One of the supported and registered Azure Geo Regions (for example, West US, East US, Southeast Asia, and so on).

trans-unit.source: Note that the location of a resource cannot be changed once it is created.
trans-unit.target: Note that the location of a resource cannot be changed once it is created.

trans-unit.source: tags: Optional.
trans-unit.target: tags: Optional.

trans-unit.source: A list of key value pairs that describe the resource.
trans-unit.target: A list of key value pairs that describe the resource.

trans-unit.source: These tags can be used in viewing and grouping a resource across resource groups.
trans-unit.target: These tags can be used in viewing and grouping a resource across resource groups.

trans-unit.source: A maximum of 10 tags can be provided for a resource.
trans-unit.target: A maximum of 10 tags can be provided for a resource.

trans-unit.source: Each tag must have a key no greater than 128 characters and value no greater than 256 characters.
trans-unit.target: Each tag must have a key no greater than 128 characters and value no greater than 256 characters.

trans-unit.source: sku: Required.
trans-unit.target: sku: Required.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are free and standard.
trans-unit.target: Valid values are free and standard.

trans-unit.source: standard2 is also valid, but can only be used when it's enabled for your Azure subscription by Microsoft support.
trans-unit.target: standard2 is also valid, but can only be used when it's enabled for your Azure subscription by Microsoft support.

trans-unit.source: free provisions the service in shared clusters.
trans-unit.target: free provisions the service in shared clusters.

trans-unit.source: standard provisions the service in dedicated clusters.
trans-unit.target: standard provisions the service in dedicated clusters.

trans-unit.source: You can only create one Search service at the free pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: You can only create one Search service at the free pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: Additional services must be created at the standard pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: Additional services must be created at the standard pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: By default, a service is created with one partition and one replica.
trans-unit.target: By default, a service is created with one partition and one replica.

trans-unit.source: Additional partitions and replicas are priced in terms of search units.
trans-unit.target: Additional partitions and replicas are priced in terms of search units.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: You cannot change the sku once the service is created.
trans-unit.target: You cannot change the sku once the service is created.

trans-unit.source: replicaCount: Optional.
trans-unit.target: replicaCount: Optional.

trans-unit.source: Default is 1.
trans-unit.target: Default is 1.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 1 through 6.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 1 through 6.

trans-unit.source: Valid only when sku is standard.
trans-unit.target: Valid only when sku is standard.

trans-unit.source: partitionCount: Optional.
trans-unit.target: partitionCount: Optional.

trans-unit.source: Default is 1.
trans-unit.target: Default is 1.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12.

trans-unit.source: Valid only when sku is standard.
trans-unit.target: Valid only when sku is standard.

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: HTTP 200 (OK) is returned when a service definition is updated.
trans-unit.target: HTTP 200 (OK) is returned when a service definition is updated.

trans-unit.source: HTTP 201 (Created) is returned when a new service is created.
trans-unit.target: HTTP 201 (Created) is returned when a new service is created.

trans-unit.source: Response Headers
trans-unit.target: Response Headers

trans-unit.source: Content-Type: This header is always set to application/json.
trans-unit.target: Content-Type: This header is always set to application/json.

trans-unit.source: x-ms-request-id: A unique identifier for the current operation generated by the service.
trans-unit.target: x-ms-request-id: A unique identifier for the current operation generated by the service.

trans-unit.source: Response Body
trans-unit.target: Response Body

trans-unit.source: For HTTP 200 and 201, the response body contains the service definition.
trans-unit.target: For HTTP 200 and 201, the response body contains the service definition.

trans-unit.source: Response Body Elements
trans-unit.target: Response Body Elements

trans-unit.source: id: The id is the URL (excluding the hostname/scheme) for this Search service.
trans-unit.target: id: The id is the URL (excluding the hostname/scheme) for this Search service.

trans-unit.source: name: The name of the search service.
trans-unit.target: name: The name of the search service.

trans-unit.source: location: One of the supported and registered Azure Geo Regions (for example, West US, East US, Southeast Asia, and so forth).
trans-unit.target: location: One of the supported and registered Azure Geo Regions (for example, West US, East US, Southeast Asia, and so forth).

trans-unit.source: tags: A list of key-value pairs that describe the resource, used in viewing and grouping resources across resource groups.
trans-unit.target: tags: A list of key-value pairs that describe the resource, used in viewing and grouping resources across resource groups.

trans-unit.source: sku: Indicates the pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: sku: Indicates the pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include:
trans-unit.target: Valid values include:

trans-unit.source: free: shared cluster
trans-unit.target: free: shared cluster

trans-unit.source: standard: dedicated cluster
trans-unit.target: standard: dedicated cluster

trans-unit.source: standard2: use only under the guidance of Microsoft support.
trans-unit.target: standard2: use only under the guidance of Microsoft support.

trans-unit.source: replicaCount: Indicates how many replicas the service has.
trans-unit.target: replicaCount: Indicates how many replicas the service has.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 1 through 6.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 1 through 6.

trans-unit.source: partitionCount: Indicates how many partitions the service has.
trans-unit.target: partitionCount: Indicates how many partitions the service has.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12.

trans-unit.source: status: The status of the Search service at the time the operation was called.
trans-unit.target: status: The status of the Search service at the time the operation was called.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include:
trans-unit.target: Valid values include:

trans-unit.source: running: the Search service is created.
trans-unit.target: running: the Search service is created.

trans-unit.source: provisioning: the Search service is being provisioned.
trans-unit.target: provisioning: the Search service is being provisioned.

trans-unit.source: deleting: the Search service is being deleted.
trans-unit.target: deleting: the Search service is being deleted.

trans-unit.source: degraded: the Search service is degraded.
trans-unit.target: degraded: the Search service is degraded.

trans-unit.source: This can occur when the cluster has encountered an error that may or may not prevent the service from working correctly.
trans-unit.target: This can occur when the cluster has encountered an error that may or may not prevent the service from working correctly.

trans-unit.source: disabled: the Search is disabled.
trans-unit.target: disabled: the Search is disabled.

trans-unit.source: In this state, the service will reject all API requests.
trans-unit.target: In this state, the service will reject all API requests.

trans-unit.source: error: the Search service is in error state.
trans-unit.target: error: the Search service is in error state.

trans-unit.source: Note: If your service is in the degraded, disabled, or error state, it means the Azure Search team is actively investigating the underlying issue.
trans-unit.target: Note: If your service is in the degraded, disabled, or error state, it means the Azure Search team is actively investigating the underlying issue.

trans-unit.source: Dedicated services in these states are still chargeable based on the number of search units provisioned.
trans-unit.target: Dedicated services in these states are still chargeable based on the number of search units provisioned.

trans-unit.source: statusDetails: The details of status.
trans-unit.target: statusDetails: The details of status.

trans-unit.source: provisioningState: Indicates the current state of the service provisioning.
trans-unit.target: provisioningState: Indicates the current state of the service provisioning.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include:
trans-unit.target: Valid values include:

trans-unit.source: succeeded: the provision is done successfully.
trans-unit.target: succeeded: the provision is done successfully.

trans-unit.source: provisioning: the service is being provisioned.
trans-unit.target: provisioning: the service is being provisioned.

trans-unit.source: failed: the service is failed to be provisioned.
trans-unit.target: failed: the service is failed to be provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning is an intermediate state that occurs while service capacity is being established.
trans-unit.target: Provisioning is an intermediate state that occurs while service capacity is being established.

trans-unit.source: After capacity is set up, provisioningState changes to either "succeeded" or "failed".
trans-unit.target: After capacity is set up, provisioningState changes to either "succeeded" or "failed".

trans-unit.source: Client applications can poll provisioning status (recommended polling interval is 30 seconds, up to a minute) by using the Get Search Service operation to see when an operation is completed.

trans-unit.source: The Update Service operation changes Search service configuration.

trans-unit.source: Valid changes include changing the tags, partition, or replica count, which adds or removes search units to your service as a billable event.
trans-unit.target: Valid changes include changing the tags, partition, or replica count, which adds or removes search units to your service as a billable event.

trans-unit.source: If you try to decrease partitions below the amount needed to store the existing search corpus, an error will occur, blocking the operation.

trans-unit.source: Key Operations
trans-unit.target: Key Operations

trans-unit.source: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an api-key.
trans-unit.target: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an api-key.

trans-unit.source: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of api-key.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of api-key.

trans-unit.source: admin key: Grants access to all operations (maximum of 2 per service)
trans-unit.target: admin key: Grants access to all operations (maximum of 2 per service)

trans-unit.source: query key: Authenticates query requests only (maximum of 50 per service)
trans-unit.target: query key: Authenticates query requests only (maximum of 50 per service)

trans-unit.source: The ability to programmatically manage the admin and query keys of your Azure Search service gives you the means for building custom tools, rolling over keys periodically as a routine security best practice, rolling over keys when an employee leaves the company, or generating and acquiring keys during service provisioning when a scripted or programmatic approach is used to deploy the solution.
trans-unit.target: The ability to programmatically manage the admin and query keys of your Azure Search service gives you the means for building custom tools, rolling over keys periodically as a routine security best practice, rolling over keys when an employee leaves the company, or generating and acquiring keys during service provisioning when a scripted or programmatic approach is used to deploy the solution.

trans-unit.source: Query keys can be acquired, created, and deleted.
trans-unit.target: Query keys can be acquired, created, and deleted.

trans-unit.source: Admin key operations are restricted to acquiring and regenerating existing key values.
trans-unit.target: Admin key operations are restricted to acquiring and regenerating existing key values.

trans-unit.source: Deleting an admin key could lock you out of the service permanently, so that the operation is not available.
trans-unit.target: Deleting an admin key could lock you out of the service permanently, so that the operation is not available.

trans-unit.source: Keys are strings composed of a random combination of numbers and upper-case letters.
trans-unit.target: Keys are strings composed of a random combination of numbers and upper-case letters.

trans-unit.source: An api-key can only be used with the service for which it was created and could change on a regular basis (if you adopt a key rollover strategy as a security best practice).
trans-unit.target: An api-key can only be used with the service for which it was created and could change on a regular basis (if you adopt a key rollover strategy as a security best practice).

trans-unit.source: Be sure to treat api-keys, especially the admin keys, as sensitive data.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to treat api-keys, especially the admin keys, as sensitive data.

trans-unit.source: Anyone who acquires your admin key has the ability to delete or read data from your indexes.
trans-unit.target: Anyone who acquires your admin key has the ability to delete or read data from your indexes.

trans-unit.target: Operations on keys

trans-unit.target: Key-related operations include the following APIs:

trans-unit.target: <html></html>List Admin Keys<html></html>

trans-unit.target: <html></html>Create Query Key<html></html>

trans-unit.target: <html></html>Delete Query Keys<html></html>

trans-unit.source: List Admin Keys
trans-unit.target: List Admin Keys

trans-unit.source: The List Admin Keys operation returns the primary and secondary admin keys for the specified search service.
trans-unit.target: The List Admin Keys operation returns the primary and secondary admin keys for the specified search service.

trans-unit.source: The POST method is used because this action returns read-write keys.
trans-unit.target: The POST method is used because this action returns read-write keys.

trans-unit.source: Admin keys are created with the service.
trans-unit.target: Admin keys are created with the service.

trans-unit.source: There are always two keys, primary and secondary.
trans-unit.target: There are always two keys, primary and secondary.

trans-unit.source: You can regenerate these keys, but you cannot delete them.

trans-unit.source: Regenerate Admin Keys
trans-unit.target: Regenerate Admin Keys

trans-unit.source: The Regenerate Admin Keys operation deletes and regenerates either the primary or secondary key.
trans-unit.target: The Regenerate Admin Keys operation deletes and regenerates either the primary or secondary key.

trans-unit.source: You can only regenerate one key at a time.
trans-unit.target: You can only regenerate one key at a time.

trans-unit.source: When regenerating keys, consider how you will maintain access to the service.
trans-unit.target: When regenerating keys, consider how you will maintain access to the service.

trans-unit.source: A secondary key exists so that you have a key available when rolling over the primary key.
trans-unit.target: A secondary key exists so that you have a key available when rolling over the primary key.

trans-unit.source: Every service always has both keys.
trans-unit.target: Every service always has both keys.

trans-unit.source: You can regenerate keys, but you cannot delete them or run a service without them.
trans-unit.target: You can regenerate keys, but you cannot delete them or run a service without them.
